comment.author: 66311327@N05
76016463@N00
comment._content: from the Wikipedia article, it seems this photo is part of the series on Villa's raid on Columbus, N.M. and the aftermath: "In 1916 he was promoted to Brigadier General and assigned to head the El Paso District during the Pancho Villa Expedition."

comment.author: 24465909@N08
comment._content: I can almost smell the canvas, leather, gun oil and cordite...

comment.author: 63860770@N07
comment._content:
Thanks rjones0856 and B-59. We will update our records with his full name. 

Let me ask, in case anyone is more familiar with military uniforms than I am. If you zoom in on his collar insignia in our high resolution tiff file, it appears to me to be that of the Inspector General. (It's a crossed sword and axe with wreath.) According to Bell's bio in the "Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the U.S. Military Academy" he was in the Inspector General's office from 1907 to 1913. Any thoughts?

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: I don't know about WW1 specifically, but at least since WW2 general officers don't wear branch insignia.  My guess would be that this photo was taken before his promotion to BG in 1916.  (Wikipedia says this photo was taken in 1915, but I don't know how they know.)
